awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Renewable Cellulosic Emulsions
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is in unlocking the potential to use aqueous colloidal emulsions instead of petroleum-based materials currently used to manufacture a multitude of products including packaging, building materials, coatings, paints, adhesives, cosmetics and even pharmaceuticals in the $26B polymer emulsion industry. Such a replacement would address the emerging national and global need to use sustainable raw materials and deliver net zero greenhouse gas emissions (GHG).  The resultant cleaner and greener products are likely to accelerate the chemical industry's shift towards bio-based products.  

This Phase I project proposes to create industrial cellulosic emulsions using solvated cellulose with the use of ionic liquids. The project aims to develop a high value, sustainable, recyclable solution that can be offered at the same or lower price as an acrylic emulsion, minimizing cost and maximizing throughput. The research will focus on the selection and pre-treatment of cellulose, the selection of ionic liquids and surfactants, emulsion process development, and optimization. Significant technical challenges are posed by the requirements for higher cellulose loadings, control of emulsion particle morphology, and emulsion stability, as well as the need to achieve an economically attractive cost structure. Additional challenges come from tuning these parameters for specific industrial applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
NSF SBIR Phase I #2213000 Renewable Cellulosic Emulsions Project Outcomes Report

Over the last decade, there has been a massive shift in awareness of the affects of fossil fuels on the carbon footprint. Fossil fuels are used to make today’s plastics and the adhesives and glues used to hold them together. In fact, even paper products are held together by petroleum-based glues. Through the Silvis Materials’ Phase I grant, Silvis proposed to make binders without petroleum products using cellulose in an aqueous solution that is ready for use in binders and adhesives.

In addition,  in reducing the carbon footprint, the proposed solution enhances sustainability, recyclability, and biodegradability for hundreds of industrial products. For example, particle board uses binders made from urea formaldehyde. On March 15, 2024, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced that formaldehyde poses an unreasonable risk to human health, with a proposal to reduce acceptable emissions from 0.75 ppm in air to 0.01ppm in air by 2031. Such regulations are causing many industries to actively seek alternative solutions, to meet such requirements. Formaldehyde is not alone.  Regulations on petroleum-based materials are being tightened globally, with Europe leading the way. Industries such as Building and Construction, Packaging, Automotive, and Textiles are just a few that will be affected.

Furthermore, social awareness to the effects of petroleum-based plastics and other products that fill up our landfills, oceans, and bodies are plentiful. With microplastics reported in our tap water, bottled water, and now bloodstream, the public is demanding alternative solutions.

Silvis is working with global Fortune 500 companies to reduce emissions and to enhance a circular economy, with products that can biodegrade or be recycled, such as packaging and building products that today end up in landfills and oceans. Today, glues, paints, and coatings are made of petroleum-based adhesives and binders. Harmful chemicals are used in the production and the end products are not environmentally friendly, deeming items such as single-use plastics as nonrecyclable.

With the support from the NSF SBIR Phase I award, Silvis was able to create renewable cellulosic emulsions that are aqueous-based and can be used to offset the use of petroleum-based materials in binders and adhesives. Through this work, Silvis has successfully created and tested a cellulosic emulsion.  Silvis was further able to derive cellulosic-based adhesives and binders which have film forming properties.  The testing of these materials has identified uses in several industrial applications. Silvis is moving forward to commercialize and scale its technology to help make the world a better place by reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the packaging and building industries.

 


Last Modified: 04/30/2024
Modified by: Patricia Ferreira
